page.description: To store a series of data values of the same data type together under the same variable name, declare the variable as an array. Arrays are useful for collecting and processing lists of information. They must be explicitly defined with the *[xb:DIM]* statement before they are used. The declaration must include the Array Size which is the maximum number of data elements the array will contain.

section.description: For example, the following statements declare an array of character strings holding five elements:
section.example: dim names[5] as C dim names[1..5] as C dim names[0..4] as C 'dim a 0 based array

section.description: It is possible to dim multiple array dimensions in one statement.
section.example: dim arr.row[1..10].col[1..5].edited as C
section.note: The first element of an array is 1 (unless the array was specifically *[xb:DIM]*med with a different initial index e.g. *[xb:dim a[0..4] as c]*).

section.description: This array can be used to collect and store a list of five names. The contents of the array elements are assigned like any other variable using the assignment operator ( = ). The number of the element in which you want to put the data must also be supplied. For example:
section.example: names[1] = "Henry" names[2] = "Burt" names[3] = "Ernie" names[4] = "Linda" names[5] = "Cheryl"

section.title: Multidimensional Arrays
section.description: Xbasic arrays can contain multiple dimensions. For example:
section.example: dim a[3,3,3] as C

section.title: Arrays of Pointers or "Property" Arrays
section.description: You can define an array of pointers. An array of pointers is referred to as a "property array". For example:
section.example:
dim ar[5] as P ar[1].mom = "Irene" ar[1].dad = "Abe" ar[2].mom = "Arlene" ar[2].dad = "Kyle"
? ar[1].mom = "Irene"
? ar[1].dad = "Abe"
? ar[2].mom = "Arlene"
? ar[2].dad = "Kyle"
ar.SORT("A","mom") ? ar[1].mom = "Arlene"
? ar[1].dad = "Kyle"

section.description: It is useful to visualize a property array like this:
The array might have more "columns". For example:
In this example, *[xb:ar[3].kids]* is 1. To sort the array on the "Kids" element, you would type:
section.example: ar.sort("","kids")

section.title: Nested Arrays
section.description: Xbasic supports nested arrays. For example:
section.example:
dim row[10] as P for i = 1 to 10 dim row[i].col[10] as C next i
row[1].col[1] = "c" row[1].col[2] = "b" row[1].col[3] = "d" row[2].col[1] = "a" row[2].col[2] = "x" row[2].col[3] = "m"
'Sort the elements of the row[1].col array. 'i.e. elements are sorted into this order: b,c,d row[1].col.sort()

section.title: Examining Arrays in the Interactive Window
section.description: If you are working with an array in the Interactive window, you can examine the contents of an array by typing *[xb:? arrayname]* in the Interactive window. For example:
section.example: dim Names[3] as C Names[1] = "John" Names[2] = "Fred" Names[3] = "Tom" ? Names = [1] = "John" [2] = "Fred" [3] = "Tom"

section.title: Dynamic Arrays
section.description: Alpha Anywhere supports a special syntax that allows you to automatically insert elements at the end of an array without having to specify the array index. The *[xb:[]]* operator can be used to simultaneously append a new entry in an array and assign it a value using the *[xb:=]* operator. Whether resizing also happens when deleting an entry depends on using the [<array>.setDynamic()] method. For example:
section.example:
dim cities[1] as C 'add a new entry to the array by omitting the array index cities[] = "boston"
? cities.SIZE() = 1.000000
? cities = [1] = "boston"
cities[] = "chicago" ? cities.size() = 2.000000
? cities = [1] = "boston" [2] = "chicago"

section.description: If the last value of the array is "empty", Alpha Anywhere will not append a new entry whe *[xb:[]]* is used. For example, consider the following array:
section.example:
dim numArr[0] as n for i = 1 to 10 numArr[] = 0 next i
? numArr.size() = 1

section.description: Alpha Anywhere interprets the value of "0" as "empty" for numeric arrays. Instead of creating an array of 10 entries with a value of 0, *[xb:numArr]* is an array with one empty entry. If the desired result is an array of 10 values, all set to zero, you disable recycling by calling *[xb:<array>.set_recycle()]* with a value of *[xb:.f.]* or use *[xb:<array>.append()]* method:
section.example:
dim numArr2[0] as n numArr2.set_recycle(.f.) for i = 1 to 10 numArr2[] = 0 next i
? numArr2.size() = 10
dim numArr3[0] as n for i = 1 to 10 numArr3.append() next i
? numArr3.size() = 10

section.description: An empty string *[xb:""]* is considered an "empty" value for a character array.

section.title: Dynamic Property Arrays
section.description: Property arrays support the *[xb:[]]* syntax. The *[xb:[..]]* can be used to add properties to the last element in the property array.
section.example:
dim a[1] as P a[1].name = "Fred" a[1].city = "Boston" a[1].age = 23 a[].name = "Tom" a[..].city = "NY" a[..].age = 35
? a.dump_properties("Name|city|age") = Fred|Boston|23 Tom|NY|35

description.p: In the script, *[xb:a[].name = "Tom"]* adds array element number 2. *[xb:a[..]. city = "NY"]* adds "NY" to the newly created array element (i.e. number 2).
While this syntax is supported, it is not a recommended best practice to use *[xb:[]]* and *[xb:[..]]* to dynamically append elements to a property array. And here's why.
If you forget to use *[xb:[..]]* to add properties and instead use *[xb:[]]*, you can end up in the following scenario:

section.example:
dim a[0] as p a[].name = "Fred" a[].city = "Boston" a[].age = 23 a[].name = "Tom" a[].city = "NY" a[].age = 35
? a.dump_properties("Name|city|age") = Fred|| |Boston| ||23 Tom|| |NY| ||35

description.p: Instead of creating two array entries with a name, city, and age property, six array entries were created with either a name, city, or age property.
To avoid this issue, use [<array>.append()] instead. The following is the recommended approach to dynamically populating a property array:

section.example:
dim a[1] as P a[1].name = "Fred" a[1].city = "Boston" a[1].age = 23
i = a.append() a[i].name = "Tom" a[i].city = "NY" a[i].age = 35
? a.dump_properties("Name|city|age") = Fred|Boston|23 Tom|NY|35

section.title: Typing Property Arrays
section.description: This example shows another common technique used with Property arrays:
section.example:
type Family Mother as c Father as c end type
'All new array entries will now automatically have a 'Mother' and 'Father' property. 'Notice that the initial array size is *[xb:DIM]*med as 0 dim a[0] as {Family}
i = a.append() a[i].Mother = "Irene" i = a.append() a[i].Mother = "Ann" a[i].Father = "Bernard"
?a[1].Father = ""
?a[2].Father = "Bernard"
a[i].age = 35
? a[2] = age = 35 FATHER = "Bernard" MOTHER = "Ann"

description.p: A *[xb:type]* can be used to define the default set of properties that should be added when a new entry is added to the property array. See [Xbasic Types] to learn more about types.

section.title: Implicit Array Declaration
section.description: When you use the *[xb:[]]* syntax to add entries to an array, the array does not need to be *[xb:DIM]*med in advance. For example:
section.example: b[] = "alpha" b[] = "beta" ?b.size() = 2

section.description: The same applies to property arrays:
section.example: workweek[].day = "Monday" workweek[].day = "Tuesday" workweek[].day = "Wednesday" workweek[].day = "Thursday" workweek[].day = "Friday" ? workweek.size() = 5
section.note: Prefer to use *[xb:<array>.append()]* when working with dynamic property arrays.

section.title: Dynamic Array Sizing
section.description: When you delete entries from an array, the array size does not change unless dynamic sizing is enabled. Dynamic sizing can be enabled by declaring the array with a size of zero (e.g. *[xb:dim arr[0] as p]*) or by calling the *[xb:<array>.set_dynamic()]* method and passing a value of *[xb:.t.]*. When dynamic sizing is enabled, deleting an entry from an array will resize the array. The following Interactive window session demonstrates an array where dynamic sizing has not been enabled because the array was declared with a size greater than zero:
section.example:
dim array[3] as c array[1] = "alpha" array[2] = "beta" array[3] = "gamma" ?array.size() = 3
array.delete(2,1) ?array.dump() = alpha gamma
?array.size() = 3

section.description: If we repeat this exercise and enable dynamic sizing, the array will decrease in size when the [delete()] method is called on the array:
section.example:
dim array[3] as c array.set_dynamic(.t.) array[1] = "alpha" array[2] = "beta" array[3] = "gamma" ?array.size() = 3
array.delete(2,1) ?array.dump() = alpha gamma
?array.size() = 2

description.p: The *[xb:<array>.set_dynamic()]* method can be used to turn on/off the dynamic sizing property of an array. The *[xb:<array>.get_dynamic()]* method can be used to determine the state of an array's dynamic sizing property.

If you *[xb:DIM]* an array with a size of 0 (and then populate the array using the *[xb:[]]* syntax or *[xb:<array>.append()]*), the dynamic sizing property is automatically assumed to be set to *[xb:.t.]*. For example:

section.example: dim array[0] as c array[] = "alpha" array[] = "beta" ?array.size() = 2 array.delete(2,1) ?array.size() = 1

section.description: This shows that an array *[xb:DIM]*med with an initial size of 0 defaults to dynamic properties on, whereas an array *[xb:DIM]*med with non-zero size defaults to dynamic properties off.
section.example: dim arr1[0] as p dim arr2[1] as p ? arr1.get_dynamic() = .T. ? arr2.get_dynamic() = .F.

section.title: Passing Arrays to Functions
section.description: When you pass an array to a function, the receiving function defines the argument as a pointer.
section.example:
Dim a[5] as C a[1] = "a value" my_function(a)
function my_function as V (arr as P) ui_msg_box("Array Value", arr[1]) end function

section.title: DIMming Arrays with Default Values
section.description: When you *[xb:DIM]* a new array, you can specify a default value for each array item. This is especially useful when *[xb:DIM]*ming arrays for use with .Net code:
section.example:
dim sb[6] as system::Text::StringBuilder = new system::Text::StringBuilder(1024) ? sb[1].capacity = 1024 ? sb[2].capacity = 1024 ...
dim nums[6] as n = rand() ? nums = [1] = 0.50457763671875 [2] = 0.172149658203125 [3] = 0.35626220703125 [4] = 0.722320556640625 [5] = 0.053955078125 [6] = 0.99090576171875
dim strs[6] as c = Rand_String(6+int(rand()*10)) ? strs = [1] = "skqesxkb" [2] = "trzafnjrijy" [3] = "ozzaofjmcboht" [4] = "lqletpztxqkhan" [5] = "xilavqnlvmofpt" [6] = "plbdelndbfhsgsc"

section.title: Creating Arrays of Objects Using <array>.clone()

description.p: The *[xb:<array>.clone()]* method can be used to assign an object into a property array initially declared as a *[xb:p]* type.
This example creates an array containing five [SQL::TableInfo] objects.

section.example: dim ti as SQL::TableInfo dim arr[5] as P arr[1] = ti for i = 2 to 5 arr[i] = ti.clone() next i

section.title: Initialize Array From Table

description.p: The *[xb:<array>.initialize_from_table()]* method allow you to optionally append to an existing array (instead of always initializing it), and to specify a list of fieldnames (rather than populating the array with every field in the source table). The array will also be resized correctly based on the number of records that satisfy the filter criteria if the dynamic sizing is enabled for the array.
For example, here is an Interactive window session using the Alphasports sample database:

section.example:
'Start with empty array (automatically dynamic) dim arr[0] as p
'Pull in NY records from Customer table... arr.initialize_from_table("customer","bill_state_region='NY'","",.f.) ?arr.size() = 8
'Now, pull in MA records from the Customer table. Notice that the append flag is set to TRUE so that records are added to the end of the array. arr.initialize_from_table("customer","bill_state_region='MA'","",.t.) ? arr.size() = 29

section.description: In this example, only selected columns are loaded into the array.
section.example:
dim fieldList as c fieldList = <<%txt% CUSTOMER_ID COMPANY FIRSTNAME LASTNAME %txt%
dim arrlim[0] as p arrlim.initialize_from_table("customer","bill_state_region='NY'","",.f.,fieldlist) ? arrlim2 = COMPANY = "Alpha Software New York" CUSTOMER_ID = "00000010" FIRSTNAME = "Bryan" LASTNAME = "Bloomberg"
